results.title: Plow that broke the plains
results.creator_credit: Pare Lorentz and United States. Resettlement Administration
results.brief_description: Depicts the ecological and human disaster that occured in America’s southwestern Great Plains region during the 1930s. The ‘Dust Bowl’ resulted from poor agricultural practices and sustained drought and is considered to have prolonged the depression. Lorentz recruited Paul Strand, Ralph Steiner and Leo Hurwitz to photograph the devastation. Their haunting images, combined with Virgil Thomson’s original film ballad and narration by Thomas Chalmers capture the tragedy that forced thousands of farmers to leave their land. Founded in 1935 as part of Roosevelt’s New Deal, the Resettlement Administration aimed to relocate impoverished farming families and poor city families. Written by Pare Lorentz.

results.title: Time piece
results.brief_description: Combines comedy and serious commentary to show one person’s life in the urban rat race. Portrays the hero, a typical young executive, as he is hospitalised and his daily life tasks flash before his eyes, alternating between realism and wild dreams. Starring Jim Henson and Enid Cafritz. Animated by Jim Henson.

results.title: Soft soap
results.brief_description: Antics of Peter and Harry, two dedicated but “out of tune” artists who devote their time obsessively to recreating the characters of Harlequin and Pierrot. Designed to draw attention to the insidious ways in which advertising techniques manipulate the consumer in the market place. Shot in Melbourne. Stars Max Gillies and Joe Bolza.

results.title: Prevention of stuttering: identifying the danger signs
results.brief_description: Introduces and distinguishes normal from abnormal diffluence in the speech of young children. Points out danger signs of developing stuttering behaviour, indicating the severity of the problem.

results.title: A Poem by Edward Lear: The Owl and the pussy-cat
results.creator_credit: John Korty, Contemporary Films and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Uses animation to portray the children’s poem ‘The Owl and the Pussy-cat’, by Edward Lear, in which the owl and the pussycat jump into their pea-green boat and sail out to the sea. Narrated by Cyril Ritchard. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: A Market town
results.brief_description: Aims to show the changing functions and morphology of Sudbury, a market town in East Anglia, England. The film looks at the modern-day aspects of this town and the effects of change on the old town.

results.title: The Magic pear tree
results.creator_credit: Wan-go Wen, Alfred Wallace and Film Dimensions
results.brief_description: A tale about a pear peddler who is greedy and selfish, a poor old man who couldn’t afford to buy a pear, and a kind passer-by who buys a pear for the old man. Points out that we should have compassion for the poor and respect for the elderly.

results.title: The Dragon's tears
results.creator_credit: John Korty, Contemproary Films and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: An animated adaptation of Hirosuke Hamada’s story of a little boy’s fearless act of inviting a dragon to his birthday party. Utilizes Japanese-style watercolour and art work. Narrated by Robert Morse. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Stones in the park
results.brief_description: The phenomenon of the rock concert is explored in this film of the Rolling Stones concert in Hyde Park, London 1969, a few days after the death Brian Jones. Includes interviews and behind-the-scenes footage. Photographed by Bill Brayne, Michael Dudds and Brian Grainger.
